question_text: According to 14 CFR part 107, how may a remote pilot operate an unmanned aircraft in Class C airspace?

options.text: The remote pilot must have prior authorization from the Air Traffic Control (ATC) facility having jurisdiction over that airspace.
The remote pilot must monitor the Air Traffic Control (ATC) frequency from launch to recovery.
The remote pilot must contact the Air Traffic Control (ATC) facility after launching the unmanned aircraft.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.41, no person may operate a small unmanned aircraft in Class B, Class C, or Class D airspace or within the lateral boundaries of the surface area of Class E airspace designated for an airport unless that person has prior authorization from Air Traffic Control (ATC).

explanation_distractors.B: Simply monitoring the frequency is not sufficient — prior authorization is required before operating in controlled airspace.
explanation_distractors.C: Contacting ATC after launching is not permitted. Authorization must be obtained prior to the operation.

question_text: Which technique should a remote pilot use to scan for traffic? A remote pilot should

options.text: systematically focus on different segments of the sky for short intervals.
concentrate on relative movement detected in the peripheral vision area.
continuously scan the sky from right to left.

explanation_correct: The most effective scanning technique is to systematically focus on different segments of the sky for short intervals. This allows the eyes to focus and detect objects that might be missed with a continuous sweep.

explanation_distractors.B: Peripheral vision alone is insufficient; pilots need systematic scanning patterns to detect traffic.
explanation_distractors.C: A continuous sweep can cause the eyes to skip over objects. Short, focused intervals are more effective.

question_text: According to 14 CFR part 107, what is required to operate a small UA within 30 minutes after official sunset?

options.text: Must be operated in a rural area.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.29, for operations during civil twilight (30 minutes before official sunrise to 30 minutes after official sunset) or at night, the small UA must be equipped with anti-collision lighting visible for at least 3 statute miles.

explanation_distractors.B: There is no requirement to operate only in rural areas during twilight or night operations.
explanation_distractors.C: Small UAS under Part 107 are not required to have transponders.

question_text: According to 14 CFR part 107, who is responsible for determining the performance of a small unmanned aircraft?
explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.15 and 107.49, the remote pilot-in-command is directly responsible for and is the final authority as to the operation of the small unmanned aircraft system, including determining its performance capabilities.

explanation_distractors.B: While the manufacturer provides performance data, the remote PIC is responsible for determining if the aircraft can perform safely for the planned operation.
explanation_distractors.C: The owner/operator may maintain the aircraft, but the PIC is responsible for determining performance.

question_text: According to 14 CFR part 48, when would a small UA owner not be permitted to register it?

options.text: If the owner is less than 13 years of age.
All persons must register their small UA.
If the owner does not have a valid United States driver's license.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 48.25, a person must be 13 years of age or older to register a small unmanned aircraft. An owner less than 13 years of age would not be permitted to register.

explanation_distractors.B: Not all persons can register — there is a minimum age requirement of 13.
explanation_distractors.C: A driver's license is not required for UAS registration.

question_text: According to 14 CFR part 48, when must a person register a small UA with the Federal Aviation Administration?

options.text: All civilian small UAs weighing greater than .55 pounds must be registered regardless of its intended use.
When the small UA is used for any purpose other than as a model aircraft.
Only when the operator will be paid for commercial services.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR Part 48, all civilian small UAS weighing more than 0.55 pounds (250 grams) must be registered with the FAA, regardless of whether they are used recreationally or commercially.

explanation_distractors.B: Registration is required for all small UAs over 0.55 lbs, including model aircraft used recreationally.
explanation_distractors.C: Registration is not limited to commercial use — recreational drones over the weight threshold must also be registered.

question_text: When may a remote pilot reduce the intensity of an aircraft's lights during a night flight?

options.text: At no time may the lights of an sUAS be reduced in intensity at night.
When a manned aircraft is in the vicinity of the sUAS.
When it is in the interest of safety to dim the aircraft's lights.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.29, the remote PIC may reduce the intensity of the anti-collision light if he or she determines that, because of operating conditions, it would be in the interest of safety to do so.

explanation_distractors.A: The regulation does allow reducing light intensity when safety warrants it.
explanation_distractors.B: The presence of manned aircraft is actually a reason to maintain or increase visibility, not reduce it. The correct criterion is the interest of safety.

question_text: What must a person, who is manipulating the controls of a small unmanned aircraft, do if the standard remote identification fails during a flight?

options.text: Land the aircraft as soon as practicable.
Notify the nearest FAA Air Traffic facility.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 89.110, if the remote identification equipment fails during a flight, the person manipulating the controls must land the unmanned aircraft as soon as practicable.

explanation_distractors.B: While notifying ATC may be prudent in some situations, the regulatory requirement is to land as soon as practicable.
explanation_distractors.C: Activating navigation lights does not address the remote ID failure requirement.

question_text: Where must a small unmanned aircraft's serial number be listed when using either standard remote identification or a broadcast module?
explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 89.115, the serial number of the unmanned aircraft must be listed on the Certificate of Aircraft Registration issued under Part 47 or Part 48.

explanation_distractors.A: The Document of Compliance is a manufacturer's document — the serial number must be on the registration certificate.
explanation_distractors.B: The Method of Compliance relates to design standards, not individual aircraft registration.

question_text: To conduct Category 1 operations, a remote pilot in command must use a small unmanned aircraft that weighs
explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.110, Category 1 operations over people require the small unmanned aircraft to weigh 0.55 pounds (250 grams) or less, including everything that is on board or otherwise attached at the time of takeoff.

explanation_distractors.B: 0.65 pounds exceeds the Category 1 weight limit of 0.55 pounds.
explanation_distractors.C: 0.75 pounds exceeds the Category 1 weight limit of 0.55 pounds.

question_text: Which Category of small unmanned aircraft must have an airworthiness certificate issued by the FAA?
explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.140, Category 4 operations over people require the small unmanned aircraft to have an airworthiness certificate issued under Part 21. This is the most stringent category for operations over people.

explanation_distractors.B: Category 3 requires a declaration of compliance, not an FAA airworthiness certificate.
explanation_distractors.C: Category 2 requires a declaration of compliance, not an FAA airworthiness certificate.

question_text: According to 14 CFR part 107, what is the maximum altitude a small UAS is permitted to fly above ground level without a waiver?
explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR §107.51(b), no person may operate a small unmanned aircraft higher than 400 feet above ground level unless operating within a 400-foot radius of a structure and not flying higher than 400 feet above the structure's highest point.

explanation_distractors.B: 500 ft AGL is not the limit — 400 ft AGL is the Part 107 maximum without a waiver.
explanation_distractors.C: 1,200 ft AGL is not a Part 107 altitude limit.
explanation_distractors.D: 2,000 ft AGL far exceeds the Part 107 400 ft limit.

question_text: After receiving a Part 107 remote pilot certificate with a small UAS rating, how often must you complete recurrent training to maintain currency?

options.text: Only once — the initial training is sufficient

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR §107.65, to maintain currency a remote pilot must pass a recurrent aeronautical knowledge test or complete an FAA-approved online training course every 24 calendar months.

explanation_distractors.A: 12 months is too frequent — the requirement is every 24 calendar months.
explanation_distractors.C: 36 calendar months is too long — currency expires after 24 months.
explanation_distractors.D: Initial training alone is not enough; recurrent training is required every 24 calendar months.

question_text: You are hired to take aerial photographs of a sporting event for commercial use. Which regulation applies to this operation?

options.text: Part 91 — General Operating and Flight Rules
Part 101 — Moored Balloons, Kites, Amateur Rockets, and Unmanned Free Balloons
Part 61 — Certification: Pilots, Flight Instructors, and Ground Instructors

explanation_correct: Commercial small UAS operations, including aerial photography for hire, are governed by 14 CFR Part 107. Any time you receive compensation for a UAS operation, Part 107 applies and you must hold a Remote Pilot Certificate.

explanation_distractors.A: Part 91 applies to manned aircraft operations, not commercial sUAS.
explanation_distractors.B: Part 101 covers unmanned free balloons and hobby rockets, not commercial UAS operations.
explanation_distractors.D: Part 61 governs manned aircraft pilot certification, not UAS operations.
